Award.AwardTitle: Evolution of substrate specificity and chemical mechanism in thiamin diphosphate dependent enzymes
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemistry of Life Processes Program in the Chemistry Division is funding Dr. Michael McLeish from Indiana University-Purdue University Indianapolis to study how enzymes evolve to choose their substrate and products. Many enzymes use thiamin, in the form of thiamin diphosphate, as a cofactor to help them speed up biological reactions. Several of these enzymes use pyruvate as a primary substrate, but have evolved to convert it to different products. This project will use directed evolution to generate new thiamin enzymes that use pyruvate. A combination of steady-state kinetics and 1H NMR and CD spectroscopy will be used to determine rate constants for the individual chemical steps in the reactions of these new enzymes and X-ray crystallography will be used to determine the structures of the evolved enzymes. The kinetics of the new enzymes will be compared to those of their naturally-occurring counterparts and related to any structural differences between these two types of enzymes. The goal of the project is to attain a fundamental understanding of the principles guiding the evolution of substrate and reaction specificity.

Most enzymes are very specialized and have evolved to recognize only one or two reactants and form one or two products. This project will explore the way in which an unusual group of enzymes is able to operate in the same manner using the same reactant, but turn the reactant into different products. Understanding this process is significant because this group of enzymes can be used in industrially important reactions. The study will require the evolution of enzymes with altered substrate specificity, and will allow undergraduate and graduate students an opportunity to explore both chemical and biological processes. They will receive training in microbiology, molecular biology, enzyme kinetics, NMR spectroscopy and X-ray crystallography. Importantly, they will also be able to integrate these studies with an outreach component that includes developing a teaching unit and a hands-on enzymology project for middle school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The enzymes that use thiamin diphosphate (ThDP, vitamin B1) as a cofactor have a remarkable ability to carry out distinctly different reactions, even when using the same substrate and, in essence, the same chemistry. How they do it? We would like to find out. More formally, this project was aimed at increasing our understanding of how an enzyme’s scaffold (i.e. size and shape) combines with a cofactor to provide catalytic efficiency, as well as enabling the enzyme to carry out a range of reactions with a variety of different substrates. Ultimately we want to be able to redesign these vitamin B1 enzymes, keeping their natural catalytic power but training them to carry out new reactions with industrial, pharmaceutical and agricultural applications.

 

To do this requires a study of both chemistry and enzyme evolution. We have focused primarily on three enzymes and have obtained X-ray structures of two of them. These structures were compared with known structures of the third enzyme, and used to make “rational” design changes so as to interconvert the activities of the three enzymes. We were able to demonstrate that making simple (yet apparently logical) changes in active site residues to evolve ThDP-dependent enzymes is unlikely to be successful. Our results suggest that this is a consequence of the many steps involved in the ThDP-dependent reaction. It seems that an improvement in one reaction step could be quite deleterious to another step. On the other hand, using a random, yet still focused approach to changing active site structure, we were able to evolve benzoylformate decarboxylase into a pyruvate decarboxylase with excellent activity. Armed with this knowledge we are now using a similar approach to evolve another pyruvate-utilizing enzyme, acetolactate synthase, to accept slightly larger substrate, 2-ketobutyrate. If successful the new enzyme will be resistant to some herbicides and could find use in the agrichemical industry. Overall, our results clearly demonstrate that rational identification of potential residues, followed by iterative saturation mutagenesis, will be the optimal approach to redesigning vitamin B1 enzymes. Further, this will very much hinge of the development of effective screening or, more likely selection conditions.

 

The project had two other significant outcomes. First, in a broader context, this project was to explore the evolution of ThDP-dependent enzymes. While much of the focus was on relationships between BFDC and pyruvate utilizing enzymes we also identified a problem with correct annotation of this family of enzymes. We have identified gene products annotated as BFDCs that, based on our earlier structure/function studies, are unlikely to be BFDCs. We cloned and characterized several of these enzymes and confirmed experimentally that the annotation was wrong. We also obtained X-ray structures of these enzymes which confirmed our predictions. These results indicate that care needs to be taken when searching for specific functional activities in the databases of ThDP-dependent enzymes,

 

Second, despite overall similar chemical mechanisms, our data show that the rate-determining steps vary for different substrates even in the same enzyme. Hence, improvement in one step may come at the detriment of another which is one of the reasons it is difficult to make “rational” changes and get predictable results. Our collaborators in Sweden have been working to establish computational models that can be used to predict the changes in energy associated with the individual chemical steps. Intriguingly, while overall energies/rates can be well simulated, calculations for individual steps are at odds with those determined experimentally. At present it is not clear whether one or both methodologies are at fault. However, if a computational method can be established, and confirmed experimentally, the requirement for developing selection or screening conditions may be reduced or even eliminated. This would make it much more simple to evolve a new enzyme with a desired activity.

 

The broader impacts of this support were training of students, establishment of international collaborations and community outreach. Overall, this grant has provided research opportunities and training for four graduate students, fifteen undergraduate researchers, three high school students and four middle school students. The graduate and undergraduate students were fairly evenly divided between male and female, while the high and middle school students were all female. Importantly, the middle school students, all from underrepresented minorities, were able to come into the laboratory and carry out hands-on experiments on a weekly basis. Finally, in addition to hosting an international undergraduate student, the PI used the project to set up ongoing international collaborations with colleagues in The Netherlands and Sweden.
